CASSELMAN-SHALIKA FORMULA APPLIED TO W^circ FOR ARBITRARY Pi, BUT ONLY VALID FOR UNRAMIFIED Pi. The node states: 'the Casselman-Shalika formula for W^circ on the GL_{n+1}-side gives W^circ(diag(varpi^{m_1},...,varpi^{m_{n-1}},1,1)) = 0 unless (m_1,...,m_{n-1},0) satisfies the dominance condition m_1 >= m_2 >= ... >= m_{n-1} >= 0.'

The Casselman-Shalika formula describes the torus values of the SPHERICAL (K_{n+1}-fixed) Whittaker function of an UNRAMIFIED representation. It applies ONLY when Pi is unramified.

The problem requires the construction to work for ALL generic irreducible admissible Pi of GL_{n+1}(F), including ramified ones. For ramified Pi (c(Pi) >= 1), W^circ is the new vector (the K_1(p^{c(Pi)})-fixed vector), NOT the spherical vector. The Casselman-Shalika formula does NOT apply to W^circ in this case. The torus support of the new vector of a ramified representation follows different formulas (Matringe, Miyauchi), and can include non-dominant weights.

Specifically: (a) For ramified principal series Pi, the new vector W^circ can be nonzero at torus elements outside the dominant cone, including elements with some m_i < 0. (b) For supercuspidal Pi, W^circ has compact support mod center, so the support is different but still not described by Casselman-Shalika. (c) Even the statement 'W^circ(diag(a,1)) = 0 unless m_1 >= ... >= m_n >= 0' needs replacement for ramified Pi.

The node's argument for n >= 2 uses Casselman-Shalika to bound the torus sum to the dominant cone {m_1 >= ... >= m_{n-1} >= 0}, which combines with the Kirillov support to produce the collapse. Without this bound, even if the Kirillov support constrained m_i <= 0, the collapse to m_i = 0 would not follow (there could be torus contributions at m_i < 0 from the W^circ side).

This is the same issue as challenge ch-b23b0a145f13161b on Node 1.3.1. The node needs either (a) a replacement for Casselman-Shalika valid for all Pi, or (b) a case analysis for ramified Pi showing the torus collapse still holds.
